description: Perform operations with integers, fractions, decimals, and complex numbers in ACT contexts

coreConcepts: Order of operations (GEMS)
Operations with fractions and mixed numbers
Complex number arithmetic: i = sqrt(-1), i^2 = -1
Powers of i cycle: i, -1, -i, 1
commonMistakes: Misapplying order of operations with nested parentheses
Sign errors with negative fractions
Forgetting i^2 = -1 when multiplying complex numbers
teachingTips: ACT places easy number-operation questions early — build confidence here
Drill powers of i: divide exponent by 4 and use remainder
Estimation eliminates 2-3 answer choices instantly

description: Apply exponent rules, simplify radicals, and work with scientific notation

coreConcepts: Exponent rules: product, quotient, power, negative, zero
Simplifying square and cube roots
Rationalizing denominators
Scientific notation conversions and arithmetic
commonMistakes: Confusing x^a * x^b with x^(a*b) instead of x^(a+b)
Forgetting negative exponent means reciprocal
Not fully simplifying radicals
teachingTips: Write out exponent rules on a reference card — drill until automatic
For radicals: factor under the radical, pull out perfect squares
Scientific notation shows up 1-2 times per ACT — quick points

description: Solve ratio, proportion, percent, and rate problems in real-world ACT contexts

coreConcepts: Setting up and solving proportions
Percent of / percent change / percent increase-decrease
Unit rates and rate conversions
Part-to-whole vs. part-to-part ratios
commonMistakes: Using wrong base for percent change (always divide by original)
Cross-multiplying incorrectly with complex fractions
Mixing up part-to-whole and part-to-part ratios
teachingTips: Percent change = (new - old)/old × 100 — memorize this
Cross-multiply is reliable but estimation is often faster on ACT
These appear in Integrating Essential Skills too — high-yield topic

description: Perform basic matrix operations and understand vector concepts tested on the ACT

coreConcepts: Matrix addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication
Matrix dimensions and when multiplication is defined
Determinant of a 2x2 matrix
Basic vector addition and scalar multiplication
commonMistakes: Multiplying matrices element-by-element instead of rows-by-columns
Getting matrix dimensions wrong for multiplication
Forgetting determinant formula: ad - bc
teachingTips: Matrix questions are rare on ACT (0-1 per test) but easy points if you know the basics
Focus on 2x2 operations — larger matrices almost never tested
Skip if time is short; come back if time remains

description: Solve linear equations, inequalities, and absolute value equations efficiently

coreConcepts: Solving one- and two-step equations
Equations with fractions and decimals
Linear inequalities (flip sign when multiplying/dividing by negative)
Absolute value equations: |x - a| = b gives two cases
commonMistakes: Forgetting to flip inequality when multiplying by negative
Only finding one solution for absolute value equations
Distribution errors: a(b + c) ≠ ab + c
teachingTips: These are early ACT questions — speed matters more than method
Backsolving works great for messy linear equations
Absolute value = 2 cases. Drill until automatic.

description: Solve systems of two equations using substitution, elimination, and graphing

coreConcepts: Substitution method
Elimination (addition/subtraction) method
Systems with no solution or infinitely many solutions
Word problems leading to systems
commonMistakes: Arithmetic errors during elimination (sign mistakes)
Forgetting to solve for the second variable
Not checking answer in both equations
teachingTips: ACT systems usually have clean integer answers — elimination is often fastest
If one variable has coefficient 1, substitution is fastest
Appears 1-3 times per ACT — practice both methods

description: Solve quadratics by factoring, completing the square, and the quadratic formula

coreConcepts: Factoring: find two numbers that multiply to c and add to b
Quadratic formula: x = (-b ± √(b²-4ac))/(2a)
Completing the square
Discriminant: b²-4ac determines number of real solutions
commonMistakes: Sign errors in the quadratic formula
Forgetting ±, giving only one solution
Not setting equation equal to zero before factoring
teachingTips: Always try factoring first — it's faster when it works
Quadratic formula is the safety net — memorize it cold
ACT loves 'how many real solutions' → just check the discriminant

description: Add, subtract, multiply, factor polynomials and work with rational expressions

coreConcepts: Adding and subtracting polynomials (combine like terms)
Multiplying polynomials (FOIL for binomials, distribution for larger)
Factoring: GCF, grouping, difference of squares, sum/difference of cubes
Polynomial long division and synthetic division basics
commonMistakes: Sign errors when distributing negatives
Forgetting the middle term in (a+b)² = a² + 2ab + b²
Not factoring out GCF first
teachingTips: FOIL is for binomials only — use distribution for larger products
Difference of squares a²-b² = (a+b)(a-b) appears constantly on ACT
Factor completely: always check for GCF first

description: Simplify and operate with radical and rational expressions

coreConcepts: Simplifying radical expressions
Rationalizing denominators (monomial and binomial)
Adding/subtracting/multiplying rational expressions
Solving equations with radicals (isolate, square, check)
commonMistakes: Squaring both sides without checking for extraneous solutions
Not finding common denominator for rational expressions
Canceling terms instead of factors in fractions
teachingTips: Always check solutions in the original equation when radicals are involved
For rational expressions: factor first, then simplify
These tend to be mid-to-hard ACT questions — worth the practice

description: Interpret f(x) notation, evaluate functions, and work with composite and inverse functions

coreConcepts: f(x) notation: input x, output f(x)
Evaluating f(a) by substituting a for x
Composite functions: f(g(x)) — do inside function first
Inverse functions: f⁻¹(x) undoes f(x), reflect over y=x
commonMistakes: Confusing f(x+2) with f(x)+2
Getting composite function order backwards: f(g(x)) ≠ g(f(x))
Thinking f⁻¹(x) means 1/f(x)
teachingTips: f(g(x)) = 'f of g of x' — work inside out
For inverses: swap x and y, then solve for y
ACT tests function notation 2-4 times per test — high frequency

description: Analyze slope, intercepts, and graphs of linear functions in various forms

coreConcepts: Slope: m = (y₂-y₁)/(x₂-x₁) = rise/run
Slope-intercept form: y = mx + b
Point-slope form: y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)
Parallel lines: same slope. Perpendicular: negative reciprocal slopes
commonMistakes: Subtracting coordinates in wrong order for slope
Confusing x-intercept with y-intercept
Forgetting perpendicular slopes are negative reciprocals (not just reciprocals)
teachingTips: Slope formula is the single most tested concept on the ACT math section
Know all three forms and when each is most useful
Graph-based linear questions: read slope and y-intercept directly

description: Analyze vertex, axis of symmetry, direction, and intercepts of quadratic functions

coreConcepts: Standard form: y = ax² + bx + c → vertex at x = -b/(2a)
Vertex form: y = a(x-h)² + k → vertex at (h,k)
Direction: a > 0 opens up (min), a < 0 opens down (max)
x-intercepts from factoring or quadratic formula, y-intercept = c
commonMistakes: Sign errors reading vertex from vertex form: (x-h) means h, not -h
Forgetting the axis of symmetry is x = -b/(2a), not -b/2a without parentheses
Mixing up maximum and minimum based on direction
teachingTips: Vertex formula x = -b/(2a) is tested very frequently
If given vertex form, read vertex directly — don't expand
ACT often asks 'what is the maximum value' — that's the y-coordinate of the vertex

description: Analyze higher-degree polynomials, exponential growth/decay, and basic logarithms

coreConcepts: End behavior of polynomials based on degree and leading coefficient
Exponential growth: y = a·b^x (b > 1) and decay (0 < b < 1)
Logarithm basics: log_b(x) = y means b^y = x
Logarithm properties: product, quotient, power rules
commonMistakes: Confusing exponential growth with linear growth
Misreading log notation — log_b(x) is not log(b·x)
End behavior errors: even vs. odd degree
teachingTips: ACT exponential questions often use real contexts (population, depreciation)
Log questions are rare (0-1 per test) but usually straightforward conversions
For end behavior: leading term tells you everything

description: Apply SOH-CAH-TOA, unit circle, trig identities, and graph trig functions

coreConcepts: SOH-CAH-TOA: sin = opp/hyp, cos = adj/hyp, tan = opp/adj
Unit circle key angles: 0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 90° and their radian equivalents
Pythagorean identity: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
Graphing y = A·sin(Bx + C) + D: amplitude, period, phase shift, vertical shift
commonMistakes: Mixing up sin and cos (adjacent vs. opposite)
Forgetting quadrant signs: All Students Take Calculus
Period formula: 2π/B, not 2π·B
teachingTips: SOH-CAH-TOA is enough for most ACT trig questions
4-7 trig questions per ACT — higher scorers need these
Unit circle: memorize the first quadrant, derive the rest by symmetry

description: Identify and apply translations, reflections, stretches, and compressions of function graphs

coreConcepts: Vertical shift: f(x) + k (up) or f(x) - k (down)
Horizontal shift: f(x - h) shifts RIGHT, f(x + h) shifts LEFT
Reflection: -f(x) over x-axis, f(-x) over y-axis
Vertical stretch/compress: a·f(x), |a| > 1 stretches, |a| < 1 compresses
commonMistakes: Horizontal shifts go opposite to the sign: f(x-2) goes RIGHT
Confusing vertical and horizontal transformations
Order of transformations matters
teachingTips: 'Inside the function' = horizontal (opposite direction). 'Outside' = vertical (same direction)
ACT tests this with specific function families — practice with linear, quadratic, and trig
Can often be solved by testing one point from the graph

description: Apply angle relationships, parallel line theorems, and triangle properties

coreConcepts: Complementary (90°) and supplementary (180°) angles
Vertical angles are equal
Parallel lines + transversal: corresponding, alternate interior/exterior angles
Triangle angle sum = 180°, exterior angle = sum of remote interior angles
commonMistakes: Confusing corresponding and alternate interior angles
Forgetting exterior angle theorem
Assuming angles are equal without justification from parallel lines
teachingTips: Draw parallel lines with transversal — label all 8 angles by pattern
Triangle properties are foundational: every geometry section uses them
These are often 'free points' early in the test — don't rush

description: Apply properties of quadrilaterals, regular polygons, and circles including arcs and sectors

coreConcepts: Interior angle sum of n-gon: (n-2)·180°
Quadrilateral properties: parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, trapezoid
Circle: circumference = 2πr, area = πr²
Arc length = (θ/360)·2πr, sector area = (θ/360)·πr²
commonMistakes: Using diameter instead of radius (or vice versa) in formulas
Interior angle formula: (n-2)·180° gives total, divide by n for each angle of regular polygon
Confusing arc length with sector area
teachingTips: Circle formulas appear on nearly every ACT — memorize them cold
For polygons: interior angle sum formula handles almost every question
Quadrilateral properties: draw each type and list what's equal/parallel

description: Calculate area of 2D figures and volume/surface area of 3D solids

coreConcepts: Triangle: A = (1/2)bh. Rectangle: A = lw. Parallelogram: A = bh
Trapezoid: A = (1/2)(b₁+b₂)h
Prism/cylinder volume: V = Bh (base area × height)
Sphere: V = (4/3)πr³, SA = 4πr². Cone: V = (1/3)πr²h
commonMistakes: Using slant height instead of actual height
Forgetting the 1/3 factor for cones and pyramids
Not matching units (area is square, volume is cubic)
teachingTips: ACT provides no formula sheet — you must memorize these
For composite shapes: break into simpler pieces, add/subtract areas
Volume questions are usually straightforward plug-and-chug if you know the formula

description: Apply distance, midpoint, slope, and circle equations in the coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Distance formula: d = √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²]
Midpoint: ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2)
Circle equation: (x-h)² + (y-k)² = r² with center (h,k)
Transformations in the coordinate plane
commonMistakes: Forgetting to square the differences in the distance formula
Reading center from (x-h)² as -h instead of h
Not completing the square to convert general circle form to standard
teachingTips: Distance and midpoint are among the most tested coordinate geometry skills
Circle equation: practice completing the square to find center and radius
3-5 coordinate geometry questions per ACT — high-value practice

description: Apply SOH-CAH-TOA, special right triangles, and the Pythagorean theorem

coreConcepts: Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c²
Common Pythagorean triples: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, 7-24-25
Special right triangles: 45-45-90 (x, x, x√2) and 30-60-90 (x, x√3, 2x)
SOH-CAH-TOA applied to right triangle problems
commonMistakes: Using the wrong side as the hypotenuse
Mixing up the 30-60-90 ratios (which side is x√3?)
Forgetting to check if a triple is a multiple of a common triple
teachingTips: Special right triangles appear on EVERY ACT — memorize the ratios
Look for 3-4-5 multiples (6-8-10, 9-12-15, etc.)
When a right triangle appears, immediately think: Pythagorean theorem or SOH-CAH-TOA?

description: Apply congruence criteria and similarity ratios to solve geometric problems

coreConcepts: Congruence: SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, HL
Similar triangles: AA similarity (two equal angles is enough)
Ratio of corresponding sides in similar triangles
Scale factor: if sides scale by k, area scales by k², volume by k³
commonMistakes: Setting up ratios with non-corresponding sides
Confusing congruence (same size) with similarity (same shape)
Forgetting that area scales by k² not k
teachingTips: Similar triangles are tested more than congruent triangles on the ACT
Look for similar triangles in complex figures — parallel lines create them
Cross-multiply the proportion and solve — straightforward once set up correctly

description: Calculate and interpret mean, median, mode, range, and standard deviation in context

coreConcepts: Mean = sum/count. Median = middle value. Mode = most frequent
Weighted averages: total = Σ(value × weight)/Σ(weights)
Range = max - min
Standard deviation: what it measures (spread from mean), not how to calculate by hand
commonMistakes: Finding median without sorting the data first
Weighted average: using simple average when weights differ
Confusing 'which has greater standard deviation' — more spread = larger SD
teachingTips: ACT loves weighted average problems — master the formula
For median: sort, then count. Even number of values → average the middle two
Standard deviation questions are conceptual on the ACT, not computational

description: Read and interpret bar graphs, line graphs, scatter plots, histograms, and box plots

coreConcepts: Reading values from bar, line, and circle graphs
Scatter plots: trend direction, outliers, line of best fit
Histograms: frequency, relative frequency
Box plots: median, quartiles, range, IQR
commonMistakes: Misreading the scale or axis labels on graphs
Confusing correlation with causation
Not reading the question carefully (asks for 'approximately' vs. 'exactly')
teachingTips: Always read axis labels and units first
Scatter plot questions: look at overall trend, not individual points
Box plot: median is the line inside the box, not the mean

description: Interpret two-way frequency tables and calculate conditional probabilities from them

coreConcepts: Reading row totals, column totals, and grand total
Joint frequency vs. marginal frequency
Conditional probability: P(A|B) = count(A and B)/count(B)
Identifying the correct denominator for 'given that' questions
commonMistakes: Using grand total instead of row/column total for conditional probability
Confusing 'A and B' with 'A or B'
Reading the wrong cell from the table
teachingTips: Two-way tables appear on nearly every ACT — practice reading them quickly
For 'given that' questions: the 'given' tells you which row or column to use as denominator
Fill in missing cells first if the table is incomplete

description: Calculate probabilities of simple, compound, and conditional events

coreConcepts: P(event) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)
P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B) if independent
Complementary probability: P(not A) = 1 - P(A)
commonMistakes: Forgetting to subtract the overlap in P(A or B)
Treating dependent events as independent
Not using complementary probability when 'at least one' appears
teachingTips: P(at least one) = 1 - P(none) is the most efficient approach
For 'or' questions: always ask 'is there overlap?'
ACT probability is usually straightforward — count carefully

description: Apply fundamental counting principle, permutations, and combinations

coreConcepts: Fundamental counting principle: multiply choices at each stage
Permutations: order matters. nPr = n!/(n-r)!
Combinations: order doesn't matter. nCr = n!/[r!(n-r)!]
When to use each: 'arrange' → permutation, 'choose/select' → combination
commonMistakes: Confusing permutation and combination
Forgetting to account for restrictions in counting problems
Calculation errors with factorials
teachingTips: Ask: 'Does order matter?' If yes → permutation. If no → combination
Most ACT counting questions use fundamental counting principle, not formulas
Appears 0-1 times per ACT but is a free point if you know the pattern

description: Solve complex rate, ratio, and proportion problems requiring multiple steps

coreConcepts: Multi-step proportion chains (rate × time = amount)
Combined work rate problems: 1/a + 1/b = 1/total
Distance-rate-time problems with multiple legs
Mixture and concentration problems
commonMistakes: Setting up the proportion relationship backwards
Adding rates directly instead of using reciprocals for work problems
Not keeping units consistent across steps
teachingTips: Break multi-step problems into single-step pieces
Work rate problems: if A takes 3 hours and B takes 6 hours, together: 1/3 + 1/6 = 1/2 → 2 hours
Label every quantity with units — this catches most errors

description: Calculate area and perimeter of composite and shaded-region figures

coreConcepts: Decomposing composite shapes into rectangles, triangles, circles
Shaded region = total area - unshaded area
Combining perimeter segments from multiple shapes
Applying multiple formulas in sequence
commonMistakes: Counting shared edges twice in perimeter
Using full circle area when only a semicircle or quarter is needed
Not accounting for all parts of a composite figure
teachingTips: Always sketch and label dimensions before calculating
Shaded area problems: figure out what to subtract
These are worth 2-3 questions per ACT and are very predictable

description: Translate real-world scenarios into algebraic expressions and equations, then solve

coreConcepts: Translating word problems: 'is' means '=', 'of' means '×'
Setting up equations from contexts: cost, profit, distance, age
Interpreting solutions in real-world terms
Choosing which variable to solve for based on the question
commonMistakes: Misidentifying what the variable represents
Setting up the equation backwards
Solving correctly but answering the wrong question (finds x when asked for x+3)
teachingTips: Define variables FIRST, then translate sentence by sentence
Backsolving is often faster than algebra for word problems
Read the question twice: what are they actually asking for?

description: Solve complex percent problems including tax, discount, interest, and successive percents

coreConcepts: Tax/tip: total = price × (1 + rate)
Discount: sale price = price × (1 - rate)
Simple interest: I = Prt
Successive percent changes: multiply the multipliers (1±r₁)(1±r₂)
commonMistakes: Adding successive percents instead of multiplying
Using the wrong base for percent change after the first change
Confusing markup and discount formulas
teachingTips: Successive percents: a 20% increase then 10% decrease is NOT a 10% increase
Practice with real contexts: sales tax, tips, discounts — students relate to these
These are 'essential skills' questions — they appear throughout the test, not just in one section

description: Convert between units and apply dimensional analysis to solve problems

coreConcepts: Unit conversion using multiplication by conversion factors
Dimensional analysis: units must cancel correctly
Common conversions: inches/feet, feet/miles, ounces/pounds, minutes/hours
Area and volume unit conversions: square and cube the linear conversion
commonMistakes: Multiplying when should divide (or vice versa)
Not squaring/cubing conversion factors for area/volume
Mixing metric and imperial units
teachingTips: Set up conversion factors as fractions so units cancel — this prevents errors
Area: 1 ft² = 144 in² (12² = 144), NOT 12 in²
ACT provides the conversion factors in the problem — just set up the chain

description: Solve problems efficiently by testing answer choices instead of solving algebraically

coreConcepts: Start with answer choice C (middle value) for efficiency
If C is too big, try A or B. If too small, try D or E
Works best for: word problems, equations with one variable, 'which value' questions
When NOT to use: multiple variables, 'which is true' questions, proofs
commonMistakes: Not starting in the middle (wastes time)
Trying to backsolve when direct algebra is faster
Substituting into the wrong place
teachingTips: Backsolving is the #1 ACT-specific strategy — every student should know it
Practice recognizing when backsolving is faster than algebra
On average, backsolving takes 2 tries when starting from the middle

description: Replace variables with concrete numbers to test which expression or equation is correct

coreConcepts: Choose easy numbers: 2, 3, 5, 10 (avoid 0 and 1 — they're special)
Substitute your numbers into the problem and each answer choice
The answer that matches your calculated result is correct
Best for: 'which expression equals', percent/fraction of unknowns, abstract questions
commonMistakes: Using 0 or 1 (too many special properties)
Using a number that appears in the problem
Not checking all answer choices (more than one might work for bad number choices)
teachingTips: This strategy turns abstract algebra into concrete arithmetic
If two answers match with your first number, try a different number
Picking numbers is slower than algebra but never gets stuck — great safety net

description: Use estimation, rounding, and logical reasoning to eliminate wrong answers quickly

coreConcepts: Round to friendly numbers: 3.14 → 3, √2 → 1.4, √3 → 1.7
Eliminate answers that are clearly too large or too small
Use sign reasoning: the answer must be positive/negative
Approximate magnitudes: 'about 100' eliminates 5, 50, 5000
commonMistakes: Over-estimating precision needed (ACT often has well-separated answer choices)
Not estimating when exact calculation would take too long
Eliminating the correct answer due to rounding too aggressively
teachingTips: On the ACT, answer choices are usually spread apart — estimation works
Even eliminating 2-3 choices improves guessing odds significantly
Best combined with other strategies: estimate first, then calculate if needed

description: Manage time effectively across 60 questions in 60 minutes with strategic skipping

coreConcepts: 60 questions in 60 minutes = 1 minute per question average
Questions get harder: #1-20 easy, #21-40 medium, #41-60 hard
Skip and return: never spend more than 90 seconds on one question
Answer every question — no penalty for guessing on the ACT
commonMistakes: Spending 3+ minutes on a hard question early
Not returning to skipped questions
Leaving questions blank (no guessing penalty!)
teachingTips: Practice with a timer from day one — pacing is a learned skill
Mark skipped questions clearly so you can find them on a return pass
If running out of time, guess the same letter for remaining questions (better than random)

description: Produce, interpret, and evaluate mathematical models from real-world contexts

coreConcepts: Choosing the right model type: linear vs. exponential vs. quadratic
Interpreting slope and intercepts in context
Using a model to predict: interpolation vs. extrapolation
Evaluating whether a model is reasonable
commonMistakes: Extrapolating far beyond the data range
Misinterpreting what the slope or intercept represents in context
Choosing the wrong model type for the data pattern
teachingTips: Modeling questions span all content areas — they're about applying math to real situations
Always ask: 'What does this number MEAN in the context of the problem?'
Linear: constant rate of change. Exponential: constant percent change. Quadratic: changing rate of change
